Yes, Clinton did face significant opposition to some of his legislative efforts during his presidency. The Republican Party gained control of both houses of Congress in the 1994 midterm elections, which led to a period of political gridlock and government shutdowns. The Welfare Reform Act of 1996, in particular, was a controversial piece of legislation that faced criticism from both liberals and conservatives. Some Democrats felt it would hurt the most vulnerable members of society, while some Republicans felt it didn't go far enough in cutting welfare programs.

The Balanced Budget Act of 1997 also faced opposition from both sides of the aisle. Some Republicans felt that it didn't do enough to reduce spending and balance the budget, while some Democrats felt it cut too much funding from programs like Medicare and Medicaid.

Clinton's attempts to pass health care reform in 1993 and 1994 were a major source of opposition, with the Clinton administration facing criticism from the health care industry, conservative groups, and some members of Congress. Ultimately, the effort failed and no major health care reform legislation was passed during Clinton's presidency.

Despite these challenges, Clinton was able to achieve several significant legislative accomplishments through cooperation with members of Congress and compromises with his opponents.
